section.title: Modals of ability
section.sectiontitle: Use can + verb to describe general ability in the present. Use could + verb to describe general ability in the past.
section.text1a: I can swim but I can't dive.
section.text2a: I could speak French but I couldn't speak German when I was at school.
section.sectiontitle2: Use was able to to talk about general ability in the past or a particular situation in the past.
section.text3a: I was able to swim 20 kilometres when I was younger.
section.text4a: I was able to save up and buy the car that I wanted.

section.title: Modals of ability
section.sectiontitle: If we want to emphasise that the action is difficult, we can use manage to in the present or past.
section.text1a: I usually manage to visit forty countries every year.
section.text2a: I managed to finish the book but it was very boring.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative we can use couldn't, wasn't able to and didn't manage to for one particular moment.
section.text3a: I wasn't able to book the tickets.
section.text4a: I didn't manage to book the tickets.
